customer_addr:
15412 Front Beach Road
Panama City Beach, FL 32413

citations.narrative:
***The main sea lion stadium pool and back holding pools are in disrepair throughout the area. The shade structure over
the public seating area is deteriorating. The staff reports that pieces of the structure fall and, “get wind-blown” into the sea
lion main show pool. There is still evidence of rust coming through the wall and running down into the water of the main
show pool which can impact water quality. The back wall along the stage is in disrepair with sections of wood broken and
paint chipping. Lastly, there are still large sections where paint is actively chipping off the walls along the water line in the
sea lion holding pools which can impact the water quality or become an ingestion hazard to the sea lions.
*** There is still cracked and broken concrete on the stage where the dolphins are being asked to “slide out” onto the
stage during the show. Damaged concrete with rough edges can easily cause skin abrasions to the dolphins. These areas
of the concrete must be maintained in good repair to protect the animals when they are asked behaviorally to come out of
the water onto the stage.
Facilities where animals are housed must be maintained in good repair to protect the animals from injury.

There is still no shade provided over multiple dolphin pools or the over the main show stage where the dolphins station for
food during training sessions with the trainers or during public guest interactions. The lack of shade makes it necessary
for the dolphins to bring their heads up out of the water and feed directly facing the sunlight during the show and during
guest interaction programs. Direct sunlight can be uncomfortable for the animals and excessive exposure to sunlight has
been linked to the development of eye abnormalities in captive marine mammals. Several of the dolphins including, "Gus",
"Turk" and "Nate" are still on daily eye medications and their conditions could be attributed to the lack of shade and direct
exposure to sunlight.
While the facility has a plan to purchase and incorporate shade cloth over the main stage and back pools, in the interim,
steps still need to be taken to provide shade for marine mammals when they are being asked to interact with the trainers
while holding their heads out of the water for training sessions or guest interactions, to avoid looking up into the sun. The
facility must provide the animals protection from direct sunlight for their health and wellbeing.
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with a facility representative.
n

narrative:
3.101(a)(1)  Repeat
   
Facilities, general. 
***The main sea lion stadium pool and back holding pools are in disrepair throughout the area. The shade structure over 
the public seating area is deteriorating. The staff reports that pieces of the structure fall and, “get wind-blown” into the sea 
lion main show pool. There is still evidence of rust coming through the wall and running down into the water of the main 
show pool which can impact water quality. The back wall along the stage is in disrepair with sections of wood broken and 
paint chipping. Lastly, there are still large sections where paint is actively chipping off the walls along the water line in the 
sea lion holding pools which can impact the water quality or become an ingestion hazard to the sea lions.  
 
*** There is still cracked and broken concrete on the stage where the dolphins are being asked to “slide out” onto the 
stage during the show. Damaged concrete with rough edges can easily cause skin abrasions to the dolphins. These areas 
of the concrete must be maintained in good repair to protect the animals when they are asked behaviorally to come out of 
the water onto the stage.  
 
Facilities where animals are housed must be maintained in good repair to protect the animals from injury. 
3.103(b)  Repeat
   
Facilities, outdoor. 
There is still no shade provided over multiple dolphin pools or the over the main show stage where the dolphins station for 
food during training sessions with the trainers or during public guest interactions. The lack of shade makes it necessary 
for the dolphins to bring their heads up out of the water and feed directly facing the sunlight during the show and during 
guest interaction programs. Direct sunlight can be uncomfortable for the animals and excessive exposure to sunlight has 
been linked to the development of eye abnormalities in captive marine mammals. Several of the dolphins including, "Gus", 
"Turk" and "Nate" are still on daily eye medications and their conditions could be attributed to the lack of shade and direct 
exposure to sunlight.  
 
While the facility has a plan to purchase and incorporate shade cloth over the main stage and back pools, in the interim, 
steps still need to be taken to provide shade for marine mammals when they are being asked to interact with the trainers 
while holding their heads out of the water for training sessions or guest interactions, to avoid looking up into the sun. The 
facility must provide the animals protection from direct sunlight for their health and wellbeing.

This inspection and exit interview were conducted with a facility representative. 
 
 n
